title: There Is a Word or Several, Must Be – Conceptual Questions (Band 6)
author: Kathleen Spivak
poem:
There Is a Word or Several, Must Be – Kathleen Spivak

Breathe these words in all languages before they’re lost, thank you and mean it. The things we take for granted and now have abandoned us. Or will. Water, air, rich earth beneath the rubble, thank you for our daily breath. Give us this day. Exhale the little thank you words, they’re quick, slip out of our pores, clean hair. A shower. Soap and aspirin. Thank you. Whoever “you” might be. Appreciation. A survival skill we never get to hone enough. Thank you, For life. For health, for the newborn baby slipping out between the hips. For wondrous eyes and little rosebud fists, thank you, sweet pea. And jump ropes, patience, teachers of the world, and teach me self-control. Migration, vanishing, the butterflies, the orange peach of the oriole. Whatever bright-eyed bird you once saw flicker past and wondered what was that? You were lucky to have it show itself. You are lucky perhaps to be it, plumage, proud breast and wings. Thank you for shelter, the blanket of morning. Of this morning. When first frost found naked earth, or when you found that one shade tree in the desert of last summer. Sun like a knife blade, now the reluctant release of pain, those precious moments when it goes away. Do you still remember having such moments? There is a word or several, must be, in all the language, for saying thank you in a world of swirl. Thank you for not yet abandoning me, my body. Wait a bit. Yes please.

questions.question: How does Spivak transform everyday language into a spiritual act through the repetition of 'thank you'?
options: By elevating ordinary gratitude into a ritual of existence
By reducing emotional intensity through repetition
By mocking politeness and formality
By contrasting gratitude with scientific logic
questions.answer: By elevating ordinary gratitude into a ritual of existence

questions.question: What tension does the poem reveal between abundance and loss?
options: Gratitude only follows total deprivation
The poet rejects material loss as unimportant
Loss is permanent and abundance meaningless
Human gratitude persists even as natural and moral abundance declines
questions.answer: Human gratitude persists even as natural and moral abundance declines

questions.question: How does the invocation 'Whoever “you” might be' redefine the concept of prayer in the poem?
options: It replaces divine belief with human indifference
It universalises faith, suggesting gratitude beyond religion
It limits prayer to personal experience
It criticises traditional spirituality
questions.answer: It universalises faith, suggesting gratitude beyond religion

questions.question: In referring to 'Water, air, rich earth beneath the rubble,' what philosophical idea about human existence is implied?
options: That gratitude survives amid environmental and moral decay
That humanity must conquer the natural world
That destruction purifies appreciation
That nature is irrelevant to spiritual life
questions.answer: That gratitude survives amid environmental and moral decay

questions.question: What is the symbolic role of the birds and butterflies within the poem’s wider meditation on impermanence?
options: They represent fleeting beauty and the fragility of life worth cherishing
They act as omens of punishment and guilt
They suggest the permanence of spiritual truth
They symbolise human control over nature
questions.answer: They represent fleeting beauty and the fragility of life worth cherishing

questions.question: How does Spivak use contrast between 'first frost' and 'the desert of last summer' to deepen her thematic focus?
options: To highlight seasonal change for visual effect only
To explore the cyclical endurance of gratitude through suffering and renewal
To emphasise the poet’s nostalgia for the past
To criticise humanity’s obsession with weather
questions.answer: To explore the cyclical endurance of gratitude through suffering and renewal

questions.question: The phrase 'Thank you for not yet abandoning me, my body' conveys which philosophical insight?
options: Consciousness depends on the fragile alliance between body and spirit
Physical health guarantees emotional peace
Life’s meaning is purely biological
The body is superior to the soul
questions.answer: Consciousness depends on the fragile alliance between body and spirit

questions.question: In what way does Spivak’s tone oscillate between reverence and urgency?
options: She alternates between joy and indifference
She contrasts gratitude with boredom
She acknowledges beauty while fearing its inevitable disappearance
She moves from personal loss to anger at others
questions.answer: She acknowledges beauty while fearing its inevitable disappearance

questions.question: What deeper meaning lies in the line 'There is a word or several, must be, in all the language'?
options: It questions whether communication is possible at all
It implies gratitude is exclusive to certain cultures
It mocks the limits of vocabulary
It asserts the universality of gratitude as an intrinsic human need
questions.answer: It asserts the universality of gratitude as an intrinsic human need

questions.question: Overall, how does Spivak’s poem function as a moral and existential statement?
options: It preaches religious faith as the only salvation
It rejects gratitude as naïve in a broken world
It portrays language as powerless against decay
It redefines survival as dependent on continual awareness and thankfulness
questions.answer: It redefines survival as dependent on continual awareness and thankfulness
